questions.text: The centrally acting antihypertensive drug is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Clonidine

Highyeild:

Centrally acting antihypertensive drugs are clonidine and Methyl dopa It is an imidazoline derivative having complex actions. Clonidine is a partial agonist with high affinity and high intrinsic activity at α2 receptors, especially the α2A subtype in the brainstem. The major hemodynamic effects result from stimulation of α2A receptors present mainly postjunctional in the medulla (vasomotor center). This decreases sympathetic outflow resulting in a fall in BP and bradycardia. Enhanced vagal tone contributes to bradycardia. Though clonidine is capable of reducing NA release from peripheral adrenergic nerve endings (release inhibitory prejunctional α2 action), this is not manifest at clinically used doses. Clonidine is a moderately potent antihypertensive.

questions.text: The active metabolite of nitroprusside acts via:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Guanyl cyclase

Highyeild:

Sodium nitroprusside is a powerful parenterally administered vasodilator that is used in treating hypertensive emergencies as well as severe heart failure. Nitroprusside dilates both arterial and venous vessels, resulting in reduced peripheral vascular resistance and venous return. The action occurs as a result of the activation of guanylyl cyclase, either via the release of nitric oxide or by direct stimulation of the enzyme. The result is increased intracellular cGMP, which relaxes vascular smooth muscle

questions.explanation:
Solution:

It can cause severe hypoglycemia.

Highyeild:

Diazoxide:- It causes hyperglycemia and not hypoglycemia It is an effective and relatively long-acting parenterally administered arteriolar dilator that is occasionally used to treat hypertensive emergencies. It acts by opening ATP-sensitive potassium channels. The most significant toxicity from diazoxide has been excessive hypotension. It inhibits insulin release from the pancreas (probably by opening potassium channels in the cell membrane) and is used to treat hypoglycemia secondary to insulinoma. Occasionally, hyperglycemia complicates diazoxide use, particularly in persons with renal insufficiency.
